entry.title: DevFest London 2024
entry.content:

Having previously presented on cloud, data, AI platforms, and responsible AI in Stockholm and India, I was naturally drawn to the AI track. The sessions were a fascinating exploration of cutting-edge topics, rangingÂ from:

  • Generative AI model performance: A deep dive into the capabilities and limitations of todayâ€™s most advanced AIÂ models.
  • Prompt injection attacks: A critical look at the security vulnerabilities of LLMs and how to mitigateÂ them.
  • Avoiding common LLM pitfalls: Practical advice on navigating the challenges of working with large languageÂ models.
  • The rise of LVMs: Insights into why Large Vision Models are poised to revolutionize how we interact with visualÂ data.
  • Harnessing the power of Gemini: Expert tips on leveraging Googleâ€™s latest AI model while staying within ethical boundaries.
  • AutoML with Vertex AI: Empowering business users to build and deploy machine learning models without coding expertise.
  • Googleâ€™s Secure AI Framework (SAIF): A comprehensive overview of Googleâ€™s approach to building secure and trustworthy AIÂ systems.

My DevFest secret weapon: granola.ai

In the whirlwind of back-to-back sessions, I discovered a game-changer: granola.ai. This incredible tool transcribed the sessions in real-time, allowing me to fully engage with the presentations without worrying about taking notes. If youâ€™re a meeting maestro juggling a packed schedule, granola.ai is your new bestÂ friend.

Tools like Ollama (https://ollama.com/) and Open Web UI (https://docs.openwebui.com/) make it surprisingly easy to experiment with LLMs on your machine, opening up a world of possibilities for privacy-preserving AI projects.

DevFest London also introduced me to some promising tools and platforms:

  • Flutterflow: (https://www.flutterflow.io/) A low-code platform for building FlutterÂ apps.

DevFest London 2024 was a whirlwind of AI innovation, insightful discussions, and inspiring connections. These passionate developers and forward-thinking companies are clearly shaping the future of technology. I canâ€™t wait to see what next yearâ€™s eventÂ holds.

Which brings me to the star of todayâ€™s post: the Eggnog Latte. Now, Iâ€™ll admit, the concept of eggs in my coffee was initially a bit jarring. But curiosity got the better of me, and I decided to give this festive concoction aÂ try.

A Brief History ofÂ Eggnog

Before we dive into the latte itself, letâ€™s take a quick trip back in time. Eggnog, with its rich and creamy texture, has a surprisingly long history. It originated from a medieval British hot milk drink called â€œposset,â€ eventually making its way to the American colonies where it became a Christmas staple. Today, variations of eggnog are enjoyed globally, from â€œrompopeâ€ in Mexico to â€œcoquitoâ€ in PuertoÂ Rico.

What Exactly isÂ Eggnog?

Essentially, eggnog is a decadent blend of milk, cream, sugar, eggs, and warming spices like nutmeg and cinnamon. Often, a splash of alcohol like rum, brandy, or bourbon is added for an extra layer of festiveÂ cheer.

Making Eggnog fromÂ Scratch

If youâ€™re feeling adventurous, hereâ€™s a simplified version of how this holiday treat isÂ made:

  1. Infuse the milk: Gently heat milk with spices like cinnamon andÂ cloves.
  2. Create the base: Whisk egg yolks and sugar until light andÂ fluffy.
  3. Temper the eggs: Gradually add the warm milk to the egg yolks, whisking constantly to prevent curdling.
  4. Thicken the mixture: Cook over low heat until it reaches a custard-like consistency.
  5. Chill: Allow the eggnog to cool completely.
  6. Add alcohol (optional): Stir in your preferred spirit.
  7. Lighten it up (optional): Fold in whipped egg whites for extra airiness.

Important Notes:

  • Safety first: Always use pasteurized eggs to avoid any risk of salmonella.
  • Variety is the spice of life: Experiment with different spices, alcohol, and flavourings to create your perfectÂ eggnog.

Whether youâ€™re a seasoned coffee lover or just looking to try something new, the eggnog latte is a delicious way to embrace the holiday spirit. So go ahead, treat yourself to this festive indulgenceâ€Šâ€”â€Šyou wonâ€™t regretÂ it!

entry.title: More than just a game: Ping Pong Diplomacy and the Wisdom of Losing

link.title: More than just a game: Ping Pong Diplomacy and the Wisdom of Losing

entry.content:
Ping pong, or table tennis as itâ€™s formally known, has a surprisingly rich history. Born from Victorian Englandâ€™s high society as an after-dinner amusement, it quickly evolved from improvised games with book â€œnetsâ€ and champagne-cork â€œballsâ€ to a globally recognised sport. But beyond the paddles and the celluloid balls lies a fascinating tale of international relationsâ€Šâ€”â€Šping-pong diplomacy.

This unlikely diplomatic tool emerged in the early 1970s, amidst the Cold Warâ€™s icy grip. An exchange of table tennis players between the US and China thawed the frozen tension, paving the way for President Nixonâ€™s historic visit to China in 1972. Who knew that a seemingly simple game could hold such geopolitical power?

But ping-pong diplomacy is more than just a historical footnote. It speaks to the deeper human capacity for connection and understanding, even across seemingly insurmountable divides. And this is where Japan enters theÂ story.

In his insightful TED Talk, Pico Iyer explores the unique philosophy surrounding ping pong in Japan. He observes a culture that fosters a competitive spirit without the cutthroat edge we often see in the West. Itâ€™s a subtle distinction, but one that reveals a profound wisdom: losing isnâ€™t the opposite of winning; itâ€™s failing to see the biggerÂ picture.

This resonated with me deeply. Iâ€™ve learned that true success lies not just in achieving victory, but in understanding the journey, the lessons learned, and the connections forged along theÂ way.

Pico Iyerâ€™s observations on ping-pong in Japan offer a valuable lesson for us all. In a world obsessed with winning, perhaps we need to embrace a new perspective. Perhaps, like the Japanese ping-pong players, we need to find the competitive spirit within ourselves, without losing sight of the shared humanity that connects usÂ all.

So the next time you pick up a paddle, remember that ping-pong is more than just a game. Itâ€™s a microcosm of human interaction, a testament to the power of connection, and a reminder that sometimes, losing can be the greatest win ofÂ all.

entry.title: Beyond the Classroom: How student tech programs shaped my journey

link.title: Beyond the Classroom: How student tech programs shaped my journey

entry.content:
As a curious individual, my journey in technology began in the 2010s thanks to student technology programs. Programs like Microsoft Student Partner, Github Education Program, and Google Student Ambassador were eye-opening experiences for me and my peers. During my time pursuing a Bachelorâ€™s in Computer Science and Engineering at Anna University, through M. Kumarasamy College of Engineering in Karur, I had the freedom to engage in various tech programs and communities. This journey led me to inaugurate and build tech communities within theÂ college.

My involvement in multiple technology communities, starting with the Microsoft Student Program and the Google Developers Group Chapter in Coimbatore, introduced me to the world of open source and cloud engineering. I had opportunities to learn, experiment, build, and educate others on modern tech stacks. These experiences opened doors to internships at various organisations and participation in events organised by companies like Microsoft, Google, Tata Consultancy Services, Wipro, Dell, andÂ others.

Through my active participation in technical associations and communities, I gained valuable hard and soft skills. Some of the most important lessons learnedÂ include,

Communication and Collaboration: Community involvement necessitates active participation in diverse activities. This includes marketing events, organising tech fests, coordinating with volunteers to conduct workshops and community-driven events, advocating for technology and tech-led products, securing sponsorships, and engaging in speaking opportunities at various forums and hackathons. Effective communication is crucial for clearly conveying ideas and ensuring successful execution. The collaboration further enhances workflows and outcomes.

Decision Making: Every piece of information received or created presents an opportunity for decision-making. In tech communities, decisions are made daily, ranging from event planning, securing sponsorships, and successfully executing events to gathering feedback and making improvements.

Delivering Value: The transformative nature of the tech industry requires communities to stay abreast of the latest releases and manage change effectively. This experience taught me valuable lessons in change management, future planning, risk mitigation, navigating challenges, and continuously updating my skills to achieveÂ success.

Program and Project Management: Being part of a community extends beyond simply delivering value; it involves learning about program management and tackling real-life problems to maintain momentum and inspire fellow students to participate in the tech world and foster innovation. This provided opportunities to learn project management using tools like Jira, Confluence for documentation, Trello, and Notion, all of which offer free versions for students.

Delegation: Understanding the nature of work and prioritising tasks based on importance and time sensitivity are essential for achieving optimal outcomes. Delegating tasks to fellow community members allows for skill development while enabling focus on critical tasks and enhancing overall productivity.

Leadership: Effectively managing and leading communities requires strong leadership skills. A leader inspires fellow members through their work ethic and indirectly influences them to adopt their approach. Key leadership qualities include empathy, honest feedback, mentorship, leading by example, and providing support for task completion.

Technology Toolbox: Like a mechanicâ€™s toolbox, a technology toolbox is essential for success. This toolbox should include productivity tools, such as Microsoft Office or Google Workspace, as well as project and product management tools. Essential development tools include, but are not limited to, programming languages like Java, Python, React, JS, and other relevant frameworks. Low-code and no-code tools for business enthusiasts, design and graphics engineering tools for designers, testing tools for testing engineers, network and security tools, and cloud and AI technologies are also crucial forÂ success.

Technology companies often recognise the potential of the future workforce and offer free licenses and tools for students to build, test, and experiment with their products and services.

Some of them are listed below, research on this topic to get more benefits.

  • GitHub Education
  • GitHub - kamath/student-free-stuff: Just a list of free software dev tools students can get
  • GitHub - AchoArnold/discount-for-student-dev: This is list of discounts on software (SaaS, PaaS, IaaS, etc.) and other offerings for developers who are students

These lessons learned from being a part of student tech communities have been invaluable in shaping my career and personal growth. I encourage all aspiring technologists to actively engage in these communities to foster their development and contribute to the ever-evolving world of technology.

entry.title: Investing in Customer Reliability: Why it matters for Cloud Providers

link.title: Investing in Customer Reliability: Why it matters for Cloud Providers

entry.content:
In todayâ€™s digital landscape, reliability is paramount, especially for businesses reliant on cloud services. Cloud providers like Google Cloud understand this and are increasingly investing in Customer Reliability Engineering (CRE). But whatâ€™s in it for them? Why empower customers to build mission-critical teams focused on reliability? Letâ€™s explore the compelling reasons behind thisÂ trend.

Time to learn about GlÃ¶ggÂ ğŸ·

GlÃ¶gg is a Swedish word, that refers to the traditional Scandinavian mulled wine, typically served warm during the winter months and Christmas season. Itâ€™s spiced with cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, and often served with almonds and raisins, offering a cosy, festiveÂ flavour.

Shifting our focus back, cloud providers are investing in customer reliability engineering for the following reasons

Reliability breeds trust andÂ loyalty

For cloud vendors, a reliable service is the bedrock of customer trust. When businesses entrust their critical operations to a cloud provider, they expect consistent uptime and minimal disruptions. By investing in CRE and providing customers with the tools and knowledge to manage their own reliability, cloud vendors foster a sense of partnership and confidence. This, in turn, translates to increased customer loyalty and long-term relationships.

Shared responsibility, sharedÂ success

Cloud computing thrives on a shared responsibility model. While providers are responsible for the underlying infrastructure, customers play a crucial role in building and managing reliable applications on top of that infrastructure. By empowering customers with CRE principles and practices, cloud vendors enable them to take ownership of their reliability, leading to a more stable and successful ecosystem for all involved.

Reducing downtimeÂ costs

Downtime can be incredibly expensive for businesses, leading to lost revenue, damaged reputation, and recovery efforts. By proactively addressing reliability concerns and equipping customers to manage their systems effectively, cloud vendors contribute to minimising potential downtime risks. This proactive approach reduces the likelihood of costly outages for both the customer and the provider.

Unlocking business value through stability

When businesses can rely on the stability of their cloud environments, they are free to innovate and focus on their core competencies. CRE empowers customers to build mission-critical teams that can ensure the smooth operation of their applications, allowing them to leverage the full potential of the cloud without being bogged down by reliability concerns

A culture of continuous improvement

Investing in CRE fosters a culture of continuous improvement within both the cloud provider and the customerâ€™s organisation. By embracing principles like blameless postmortems and proactive monitoring, both parties can identify areas for optimisation and continuously enhance the reliability of theirÂ systems.

In conclusion, cloud providers are investing in Customer Reliability Engineering (CRE) because itâ€™s a strategic imperative in todayâ€™s competitive market. By empowering customers to build mission-critical teams focused on reliability, theyâ€™re not just selling services, theyâ€™re building long-term partnerships based on trust, shared success, and a commitment to delivering exceptional digital experiences.

entry.title: AI Infrastructure business is a pricey endeavor

link.title: AI Infrastructure business is a pricey endeavor

entry.content:
While AI might seem magical, in the business world, itâ€™s about automating tasks using machines that learn from data and real-world situations. Advancements in Natural Language Generation (NLG) have led to Large Language Models (LLMs) and their ongoing improvement.

The hidden workhorse: AI Infrastructure

Often overlooked is the crucial role of AI engineering. It involves managing the data that fuels AI models and ensures they deliver the expected results when prompted. Handling this data at scale requires a robust infrastructure for both data and AI engineering workloads. Imagine an iceberg; the visible tip represents the AI system, while the vast, hidden part is the supporting infrastructure.

Itâ€™s exciting to see how your hand-drawn iceberg floats in real life. Thanks to Sketchplanations for introducing me to Iceberger, where you can create your iceberg and watch it float. Give it a try and be a kidÂ again!

Iceberger

Why starting an AI Infrastructure company now might beÂ tough

This section doesnâ€™t discuss the basics of building infrastructure or AI systems. However, venturing into AI infrastructure right now might not be ideal. Hereâ€™s a realistic perspective based on experiences within the AI ecosystem:

Limited Market for Niche Solutions: Imagine starting a business to support a single vendor needing custom infrastructure for on-premise LLMs. This approach might not attract many future customers.

Challenges in a Competitive Landscape: The existing market is competitive. Convincing customers to move away from established cloud vendors with their comprehensive governance, platforms, and tight integration is difficult.

Key considerations for a successful AI Infrastructure startup

Here are some crucial aspects to consider for a future-proof AI infrastructure company:

  1. Extensive research and development: Investing heavily in R&D is essential to stay ahead of the curve and meet evolving customerÂ needs.
  2. Technology stack: Innovating the right, scalable and flexible technology stack is crucial to accommodate current and future customerÂ demands.
  3. Marketing and sales strategy: Develop a clear plan for marketing, sales communication, collaboration, and partnerships.
  4. Streamlined customer onboarding: Simplify the onboarding process, considering the fast-paced changes in the AI landscape.
  5. Predicting customer needs: Anticipate customer expectations to tailor your go-to-market strategy effectively.
  6. Focus on broader solutions: Instead of hyper-niche solutions, target broader problems affecting a wider range of customers.
  7. Understanding established players: Large companies have complex needs. A startup might not be able to solve all their problems, as changes in strategy and new product adoption can trigger internal changes and unique challenges.
  8. Cost optimization in a cloud-native world: Helping cloud-native customers find their sweet spot for cost savings and system efficiency is a significant challenge.
  9. Idea protection: While intellectual property theft is a concern, established companies can quickly adapt and implement innovative ideas.

Conclusion

The AI infrastructure space is challenging but holds promise. Careful consideration of the market landscape and a well-defined strategy are crucial forÂ success.

entry.title: Class SRE implements DevOps
entry.content:
I am writing this blog post after taking a course from Google Cloud Boost Skills. It was fascinating to learn about the significance of SRE (Site Reliability Engineering) and DevOps in organizations of anyÂ size.

Before diving into the importance of SRE and DevOps, letâ€™s understand what DevOpsÂ is.

Traditionally, developers and operators (the team that deploys and manages systems/applications) functioned in silos, leading to numerous challenges. This separation resulted in increased technical debt, longer time-to-market for solutions, and poor communication and collaboration between teams. Thanks to DevOps practices, teams are now structured in a more integrated manner to address both development and operational needs. This integrated approach reduces time-to-market with calculated risks, introducing terms such as SLA and SLI into theÂ mix.

SLA (Service Level Agreement): A commitment between a service provider and a client regarding the expected level ofÂ service

SLI (Service Level Indicator): A measure of the service level provided to theÂ client

Connecting five key touchpoints highlights the thin line between SRE and DevOps. Essentially, Class SRE implements DevOps for severalÂ reasons:

1. Reduce Organizational Silos: Siloed working environments attract numerous engineering problems. By reducing silos, organizations can bring ideas to life more optimally.

2. Accept Failure as Normal: Making mistakes is human, but learning from them is crucial. A blameless culture that performs postmortems of problems enhances the learning curve and encourages teams to take ownership.

3. Implement Gradual Change: Change is essential for growth. The technology landscape is embedded with change management at its core. Software engineering teams live by agile values, are open to changes, and consider rapid development and deployment crucial. Understanding consumer requirements, listening to feedback, and analyzing user data are vital for mutual success. Canary and blue-green deployments exemplify this approach.

4. Leverage Tools and Automation: Introducing automation empowers software engineering teams. This can range from simple tools for capturing screenshots to advanced AI companions for auto-coding. Integrating such systems into workflows boosts company productivity.

5. Measure Everything: While empowering software engineering is crucial, defining success criteria and measuring them is even more critical for business success. Defining KPIs (Key Performance Indicators) enables teams and individuals to enhance their workÂ methods.

Stay tuned for the next post where we will dive deeper into SLA, SLI, and similarÂ terms.

entry.title: The AI Maturity Checkup: Get your organisation in shape

link.title: The AI Maturity Checkup: Get your organisation in shape

entry.content:
AI maturity refers to the degree to which an organization has successfully integrated artificial intelligence (AI) into its operations, culture, and decision-making processes. It is a measure of how well an organization leverages AI to achieve its business goals, create value for its customers, and manageÂ risks.

Key aspects of AI maturity:

1. Strategy: A clear AI strategy aligned with the organizationâ€™s goals, clearly defining use cases and their potential businessÂ impact.

2. Data: Robust data infrastructure to support AI requirements, emphasising governance, readiness, quality, privacy, and security. This ensures AI models are fueled with relevant, reliable, and responsibly handledÂ data.

3. Technology: Careful selection of software tools and platforms that best support the computing demands of AI model development, testing, deployment, and continuous monitoring.

4. Talent: A skilled workforce comprising AI professionals, data scientists, data engineers, leaders, and subject matter experts. They are essential for driving and sustaining AI adoption.

5. Culture: A culture that fosters innovation, experimentation, and data-driven decision-making. This promotes continuous improvement for better customer outcomes. Ethical considerations and effective change management are integral to thisÂ culture.

6. Governance: Frameworks, processes, and best practices to guide the responsible and ethical development of AI solutions, ensuring alignment with legal requirements and customer interests.

Levels of AI Maturity: AI maturity is often visualized as a spectrum or scale with several levels, typically rangingÂ from

1. Nascent: Limited understanding of AI, characterized by ad-hoc experimentation.

2. Developing: Formalization of an AI strategy begins, with initial projects underway.

3. Operational: AI is integrated into some business processes, yielding measurable results.

4. Transformative: AI is a core part of the companyâ€™s DNA, driving strategic decisions and creating significant competitive advantages.

Letâ€™s explore AI maturity for organizational success, recognizing thereâ€™s no one-size-fits-all approach. From my experience working with Nordic enterprises, Iâ€™ve identified three key dimensions within the AI maturity diagnostic process:

  1. Current State Assessment: Conduct a thorough analysis of the organizationâ€™s current AI capabilities, including infrastructure, data readiness, talent pools, and existing AI applications.
  2. Maturity Benchmarking: Compare the organizationâ€™s AI maturity with industry standards and identify areas for improvement.
  3. Gap Analysis and Recommendations: Provide detailed recommendations and a roadmap for achieving higher AI maturity.

In our upcoming articles, weâ€™ll explore the power of current state assessments, the importance of benchmarking in the AI race, and how to learn from leading AI-first companies to identify and overcome challenges quickly.
